prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 Continuum: Taurus binaries (Part 1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to map the continuum emission of Taurus binaries and multiples, amounting to a total of ~100 pairs and multiples distributed over 50 pointings. Since there are measurements in the literature for *wide*, *bright* Taurus binaries in Band 6, this set of pointings is a subset of the total number in this project. Resolution is maximum allowed for baselines shorter than 2 km in Band 4. This requirement is to distinguish disk pairs as often as possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is the technical justification for the chosen correlator configuration.
This is technical justification for the resolution and largest angular scale.
This is the technical justification for bandwidth This is the technical justification for bandwidth

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 Continuum: Taurus binaries -- faint sources (Part 1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to map the continuum emission of Taurus binaries and multiples, amounting to a total of ~100 pairs and multiples distributed over 72 pointings. Band 4 has more targets than Band 6 because measurements at these longer wavelengths are scarcer and thus we need to include the brightest objects. Resolution is maximum allowed for baselines shorter than 2 km in Band 4. This requirement is to distinguish disk pairs as often as possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is the technical justification for the chosen correlator configuration.
This is technical justification for the resolution and largest angular scale.
This is the technical justification for bandwidth This is the technical justification for bandwidth

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Stellar multiplicity in young stars can have an important effect on planet formation. Until now, observations have assessed the role of multiplicity in terms of the amount of disk flux/mass around stars as a function of companion separation. However, the outcomes of tidal effects are not restricted to their impact on disk sizes (and total fluxes). The additional forcing exerted by a stellar-mass companion can significantly change the way dust particles drift and collide with each other, therefore altering the process of grain growth. In this ALMA Cycle 3 proposal, we aim to measure the changes in grain growth as a function of binary separation using high sensitivity dust-continuum observations at two different frequencies (Band 4 and Band 6) for a selected sample of disk-bearing young stars in Taurus. These observations will allow us to measure the dust opacity spectral index beta for a variety of disk pairs, with enough sensitivity to reach separations of a few tens of AUs. The wide range of pair semi-major axes in our sample will allow us to measure, for the first time, the variability of beta with pair separation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, University of
